conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first-choice school, and I would be excited to enroll and commit if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top true choice. All schools rank me first in priority, so applying immediately to my top option maximizes my outcome and should secure an instant match before any uncertainty from others' applications matters.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_B and would be excited to welcome you to our community. Please confirm your enrollment per the process—congratulations!
conversation.thought: Student_A is the top-ranked student on School_B's true priority list. They have applied in round 1 and explicitly state School_B is their first choice and they will commit if admitted. With quota 1 and no higher-priority candidate possible, accepting now secures the best attainable match and avoids any risk of losing Student_A to another school in later rounds.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions Committee, I’m Student_B. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m very eager to join your program and community. If admitted, I would accept immediately and commit fully. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_A, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked second. Since School_A will likely receive an application from Student_A (ranked above me), my best chance is to apply immediately and clearly express strong commitment in case Student_A goes elsewhere. If rejected, I can pivot quickly to my next choices in later rounds.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_A. Please confirm your commitment so we can finalize your enrollment steps.
conversation.thought: My true priority ranks Student_A above Student_B, and I have only 1 seat. However, in this round only Student_B applied to me, and Student_B lists School_A as their first choice and commits to enroll if accepted. Waiting for Student_A is risky because Student_A prefers School_B first and may never apply to School_A. Accepting Student_B now secures a high-priority (2nd) student and fills my quota with a committed match.

conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions—I'm Student_E. School_E is my first choice because I value the community and would be excited to contribute actively to campus life. I’m ready to commit if offered a place. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top-choice School_E to maximize the chance of matching there. With identical school priorities ranking me last, I should secure any available seat by going for my highest preference first rather than risking it filling while I talk elsewhere.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing why School_E is your first choice. We appreciate your commitment and enthusiasm for our community.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. Welcome!

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and received an [APPLY] from Student_E, who ranks last on our true priority list. However, in this round no higher-priority students (A–D) contacted us. Given Student_E lists School_E as first choice, accepting now secures a match and avoids the risk of ending unmatched if higher-priority students never apply to us (they all rank School_E last). Thus, accepting Student_E is optimal under current market signals.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_D and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m very motivated to join your community and would be honored to take the available seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately rather than risk losing the single seat. Although School_D’s priority ranking places me below A/B/C, an early application is still my best chance to secure my first choice before the market moves on.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_D and would be happy to welcome you to our community.
conversation.thought: Student_D applied and ranks School_D as their first choice, so acceptance is likely stable. However, on School_D’s true priority list, Student_D is 4th (behind A, B, C). In the broader market, Student_A prefers B>A>C>D>E; Student_B prefers A>C>B>E>D; Student_C prefers C>B>A>D>E; Student_E prefers E>B>A>C>D. None of A/B/C/E rank School_D first, so it is unlikely they will apply to School_D in round 1, and even if they do later, they may only do so after being rejected elsewhere. Given quota=1 and no higher-priority applicants in the current inbox, accepting Student_D now secures a match with a student on our acceptable list and reduces risk of ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_C and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m applying because your academic environment and overall fit align best with my goals, and I would be excited to enroll if admitted. Thank you for considering my application. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I am behind Student_A and Student_B everywhere. To maximize my chance at my highest-ranked option, I should apply to School_C immediately rather than risk losing its single seat to higher-priority applicants who also rank it highly (notably Student_B).

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. We appreciate your interest and are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. We look forward to having you join our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_A highest, then Student_B, then Student_C. I currently have quota 1 and only Student_C has applied to me this round. However, Student_A ranks School_C as 3rd choice (likely to apply to School_B or School_A first), and Student_B ranks School_C as 2nd choice (may apply to School_A first). Student_C ranks School_C as 1st choice and has already applied, making this a secure match now. Given the one-shot message constraint per round and risk of ending up unmatched if I reject waiting for higher-priority students who may never apply, accepting Student_C is the best move to fill my quota with an acceptable candidate on my list.
